comments.commentBody:
Back in 2007 the economy was "looking pretty good", before Wall Street's casino of a financial system crashed in 2008. Today, we're in the same situation, except the bubble of speculation is much bigger.

The economic role of presidents is "not much" because the majority of them are puppets of Wall Street. Some exceptional presidents that weren't tools of Wall Street were Lincoln and FDR. Lincoln bypassed Wall Street by having the government take over the creation and issuance of the currency with the greenback system, while FDR passed Glass-Steagall and wrote off the worthless gambling debt, while also having the Reconstruction Finance Corporation lend direct credit to industry to build the country back up. Obama has refused to re-enact Glass-Steagall, helping set the stage for another economic implosion. The biggest U.S. banks, which now reportedly have some $240 trillion in derivatives exposure, have been allowed to pile up almost all of it on their FDIC-insured commercial banking units since Glass-Steagall was eliminated in the 1990s.

Obama supported the outrageous mid-December power play by which Wall Street banks forced Congress to grant FDIC insurance to their commodity and credit derivatives. That mid-December bribery-and-corruption orgy was led by Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase, and Morgan Stanley banks (along with their stickman, Barack Obama).

"Obama has never really focused on job growth" - not true.
The comprehensive jobs bill in 2010, blocked by GOP in Senate, that required raising taxes by wealthy to pay for the investments in US economy, was a major effort to create at least 2 mlns jobs. Dems had 60 votes in Senate for only 16 weeks in 2009-2010.

That's my experience as well, albeit I've worked with prisoners in the forensic section of a general hospital. Prisoners usually make the very best patients (perhaps because they have no choice?). They are universally polite and respectful of the medical team. Our treatment plans can be enacted because there are no external hindrances that thwart our care (e.g. prior authorizations). This, of course, is not to overlook their character issues, but my job is to treat illness and not be the judge and jury.

As you stated, prisoners are the only people in the US who have a right to healthcare. For the rest of us, healthcare is a privilege subject to insurance company wishes, the vagaries of American politics and the profit motive. Wouldn't it be great if every American could have this level of access to care with physicians having the ability to practice medicine without external hindrances? Sounds like universal healthcare to me.

I am a doctor who has worked in several state prisons.
Prisoners are the only Americans who have a right to 100% free health care and have pro bono lawyers. If you are desperate for medical care, go to prison.
Most will tell you their crime if you ask.
Almost all prisoners are nice people with violent tempers, sociopathic tendencies, or the wrong friends, but they are good in manipulating the system and not trustworthy Even most child molesters do not consider themselves evil and are nice to their victims.
They often ha little access to medical care before prison or bad personal care including drug abuse, alcoholism, HIV, and hepatitis C.
Kalinda may jsut go on the lam and disappear. Doubt that she goes to prison.

You are right--that's a significant sum to suddenly show up in his account after they all emptied the coffers to create the firm.

Hmm.

Don't remember if it was mentioned in the show, but Cary's bank account would have been frozen during bail time. (I personally found it hard to believe that among all the partners in a law firm, they had a hard time to raise bail money.)

A fast moving episode that left me with some questions. Where did the money in Cary's bank account come from? I thought I saw over $250000 in there, but he didn't have that kind of cash when they were scrounging for bail money.

And wouldn't Diane have spoken to Kalinda about the metadata before downloading it from her computer? That seemed unlike the usual efficient communication we have come to expect from these two.

I guess this is a good setup for Kalinda to exit the show by being sent off to prison, as opposed to being killed by Bishop. Will Cary wait for her, as she promised to wait for him? Doubtful.

The Good Wife is my favorite TV  hour. Alicia's ability to knock it out of the park with her verbal  volley with her husband proved to be the evening's  highlight.Alicia is a class act! Her ability to maintain her grace and dignity is a constant entertainment. Modern women are constantly questioning themselves ,Alicia's on screen proformace is pure gold!!!
Proof again, there's no accounting for taste.

This is a brilliant play with five outstanding acting performances. It is an example of theater that makes us think in complex ways about the way we live now. It is by turns gripping and fascinating. In the central role, Hari Dhillon (whom I had never seen nor heard of) is so compelling that his interpretation is still vivid in my thoughts more than a month after attending the play. The play won the 2013 Pulitzer Prize for Drama for Ayad Akhtar and it was richly deserved. I am in no way connected with this show or anyone in it, but feel that theater of this quality must be supported on Broadway or its theaters will become venues for mega-musicals and traditional plays with stars famous from television or film.

Can we nonetheless say that the economy is doing better than if the other party held the White House?

No

Because if the other party held the White House they would have used any means necessary to stimulate the economy. "Revenue neutral" tax cuts that produced deficits, infrastructure spending, military spending, whatever. Reagan's tax cuts weren't expansionary because of supply-side economics, they were expansionary because they produced large deficits. Bill Clinton left office with a budget surplus that George W. Bush turned into a deficit. Republicans are only interested in balanced budgets when Democrats are in charge and when they can use the deficits as an excuse to cut programs that they don't like.

There may be a few true believers in the Tea Party, but history is clear: Republicans will run deficits when their election chances are dependent on them.
let us have a less breathless account next week, please.
We keep hearing that the Americans and their bad taste ruined a proper British show, which hardly explains why the ratings are proportionally higher in Britain than they are in the US.

Oh give me a break.  The Brits produce just as much junk, on a per capita basis, as the US - maybe more and junkier.  It's just that they keep the worse of it to themselves, but even some of the stuff that does get exported is pretty awful.  WGBH, our local PBS station and the importer of Downton, when they're not showing infomercials, fills their schedule with dreary British sitcoms that would deservedly be cancelled within two weeks in this country.  However, since they're  done with an accent certain Americans can't help but be impressed and think it must be good.  I know someone who stuck his nose in the air and wouldn't dream of ever watching "Law and Order", but enthusiastically binged on the British version.  The fact that they were basically just re-shooting scripts from the original American series was meaningless to him.  It was British so it must be better.

This program had a bit of an edge until they noticed that American audiences preferred bathos and the formulaic.  Oh, well...it's likable enough but the gushing and the award nominations are out of order, especially considering the outstanding work many of the actors have done in the past.
Go to the www.slate.com website and search for "George Clooney Downton Abbey."
Google "downton clooney" and articles and the video will come up.

The Downton Abbey parody is in two parts:

part 1: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ryo7fqdmcGQ

part 2: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dO4UMQIsCW0
What "nine-minute fundraising video"? Is this something we're supposed to be familiar with? It's mentioned as if it is, but I have no idea what he's talking about. Is it something we can see?

I suspect the plot is working toward a discovery that Daisy is learning disabled--didn't she make some comment about the words being a jumble? (This indicates one reason why there are supposedly so many more learning disabilities now; Daisy could very well have been severely dyslexic and done an excellent job of cooking in the 1920s, but today, any instruction would have included so much paperwork that she would not be able to cope.) And there has to be some connection between Daisy wanting to learn math and the teacher meeting the staff.
I want to see Daisy break out and do something truly fantastic, historical realism be damned. Some kind of make-everyone's-jaws-drop amazing. (And no, studying math at night isn't what I mean.)

This season is different from past seasons (generally).   Most seasons started off with some kind of big event and then spent the season resolving it and then with a cliffhanger of some kind for the next season.   This season builds more gradually.

I also felt Season 5, Episode 1 fell flat. I was hoping this last season was going to show some real drama and some real desperation.

Hasn't happened yet.

She is leaving the show, but I don't know if she will be there for the rest of this season.  I  don't know if this is the best way of  developing a story line for her to leave the series.  Cary can't be tried again.  If they find out that Kalinda hacked to cop's computer she will be going to jail, despite the fact that they had evidence that would have gotten Cary off.
Indeed, the hack is relatively easy to discover.
So close to not needing Kalinda's illegally created information. She's going up the creek. (Down the river? Off to a new career?)

And Fellowes explained that they had to kill him off because he was a major character. A minor character (Alfred, for example) can be sent off to a different job or to another country, but it's harder to explain the disappearance of a major character. Which, by the way, is why I think Gregson is dead--there are practical problems to hiring an actor, writing him out of a show for a few seasons, and then bringing him back. At least there are in Britain, where the seasons are so short that most actors doe several different roles at once, unlike in America where an actor may take a year to do one movie role and then return to a TV show.

Funny how tastes vary.  Matthew couldn't croak fast enough to suit me.  I found him insipid and quite unattractive; Mary's worship of him was never at all convincing.  So glad he is gone.. Lord Gillingham while a bit winsome for my taste would be an improvement.

JF said a servant like Gwen or O'Brian, can always find another job, but family needs a more final explanation.
And Dan Stevens decided to bail when the season was already half written--unlike Jessica Brown Findlay, who gave notice much earlier.
It's also harder when they're married, since their "spouse", who may want to stay on, and why not, has to be accounted for as well.

Wonderful piece! Please add a link to the George Clooney bit, as there is a lot of overlap in his fan base and Downton's.

Isis the dog is still named Isis. Brave call, Julian Fellowes.

But I'm still not over Matthew's death. The wind went out of the show's sails when they killed him off. The new suitor just isn't the same, and I think the show needs another grand storyline to really make it spark. (George Clooney, where are you?) There are too many little stories that don't really grab me. It's like Gone With The Wind without Rhett Butler.

Every episode of "Downton" in which Carson proves that HE's the real lord of the manor reminds me of Somerset Maugham's aphorism, "American women expect to find in their husbands a perfection that English women only hope to find in their butlers."

Good point.  However, perhaps they just need to get the plotline up and running again and then subsequent episodes will unfold a little more leisurely.  (I seem to recall this also happened during the first episodes of Seasons 3 + 4.)
This is the British way.  Very East Enders.
No, they've been doing this choppiness for a couple of seasons now.  Very annoying for those of us with a normal attention span.

I do like Downton Abbey, but the choppiness of the editing is driving me nuts. I find myself longing for a conversation or a scene that lasts more than a few seconds. I keep watching but feel like the producers have no confidence in the viewers' attention spans. It's rather like a grown-up Sesame Street, although Sesame Street does have some longer scenes.
Great service for those of us far from NYC and/or with mobility problems.
Sorry, this is the Bates and Anna Show, don't you know?  Who killed Mr. Green will be the central plot line for quite a while.
So absolutely tired of the who killed Mr.Green plot line

"And there's Bates the Avenging Angel. If I were Thomas, I'd think twice."

This is brilliant:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JUbQYCUGee4

I so agree about the lack of art or even hobbies. The lord of the real manor house used for Downton actually went on expeditions and found King Tut's tomb! And there was a madness for airplanes among the aristocratic English at this time - surely one of the characters could learn to fly - Edith taking off in a long scarf and leather flying cap would be wonderful.

"the teacher would never have done that in reality"
Well, this is Yorkshire. Daisy Lewis said that her character's backstory is that she's an Oxford graduate, from a well-off (upper middle class) farming family, most of whom rose while the lordly classes were losing their property--to them. So she'd have grown up with blunt table talk, some of it about the fools with titles going to the wall. This is a pretty good summary of what was really going on at the time:
http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/features/features/8454627.So_where_is_Downton...

The acting sometimes seems bad. In each episode, the plot seems to go off the rails somewhere (the school teacher, who is keen on Tom, would really insult the lord at his own anniversary dinner?). And no one in the abbey does anything creative all day--no music, no art, no writing a novel--even a lesbian soft-core one (at least not yet). Still, each year I keep watching Downton Abbey. Maybe one reason is that unlike most dramas today, including British ones, it isn't populated with serial killers, psychopaths, sadists, corrupt politicians, and morally compromised law officers. And there's Bates the Avenging Angel. If I were Thomas, I'd think twice.

Anna Chancellor is not a descendant of Jane Austen. Austen had no children, so she has no descendants. I have no doubt that Anna Chancellor is a great grand niece however many times removed, but she is not Austen's descendant. And now for my tongue-firmly-in-cheek scolding--Viseguy, have you learned nothing whatsoever about family lineage from watching this show?

I stand corrected and chastised. What I've learned from Downton Abbey has been a case of diminishing returns with each passing season, but this hasn't stop me from watching it, of course.

As for those complaining about Mr. Bayard's recap being "breathless", I say au contraire. He's trying to pump oxygen into the drawing room.

Viceguy, as to the diminishing returns of watching the show and continuing to watch it, I agree. I also agree about the fun in Bayard's recap. My previous comment was very "tongue in cheek," a failed attempt to sound like the Dowager Countess.

I hope we see more of Lady Anstruther (Anna Chancellor, a descendant of Jane Austen, no less) as the season unfolds -- and I mean that in the most innocent way possible. (If you believe that last bit, I have a bridge to sell you.)

Oh boo hoo.

Annie has to read mail she doesn't like.

Isn't that what assistants are for? Ah the trauma of having written something that made a lot of people think. I think she needs to review her post-modernism class notes and remember that once it hits the shelves it no longer belongs to her. The Ur text is out there and the audience will do as it sees fit.

Maybe she needs someplace more remote than Wyoming. I hear there are over winter jobs at McMurdo station.

Warmly received by critics, maybe, but less by audiences. Tepid applause speaks louder than reviews. The reception was definitely weak at the performance I attended, when the house was about 80% full of metro-area theatergoers (this is certainly not a tourist show). It won the Pulitzer Prize for drama by checking the politically correct boxes. In 2015 let's hope "Our Lady of Kibeho," a truly worthy contender, wins that award.
Least imaginative show on TV.
Not really, especially when you consider that the clothing and furnishings could actually be considered as one of the characters.
I forgot how repetitive this show's plots are - everything happens and nothing happens.
"Lady Edith chose to set fire to her bedroom"
Anna Chancellor's way with "You're a very naughty boy!"

I took that as a small joke--the sort of thing my family might say. (On a trip to England, a relative got sick the first day and later lamented that she had been planning to shop for souvenirs that day. "Oh, well," she said, "It's  my vacation and if I want to spend it throwing up it's no one else's business.")
Best line of the episode -- Lady Mary, "I'm going upstairs to take off my hat."
Yes in a Upstairs Downstairs  this crossing of the class line happened and it was very interesting and believable

Lord G was almost involved with a maid earlier and Tom was involved with a maid in an earlier season.
For that matter, Tom himself was once a servant who ran off with one of Lord G's daughters.

Jf took pains to state elsewhere that Tom, as a chauffeur, was an employee, and a skilled one, like the (unseen) engineers who maintain the electrical power in the house. The actual servants, like O'Brian, noted that it wasn't his place to be in the house as much as he was.

Even this delightful turn-of-the-century costume drama should have a more accurate portrayal of the sexual history of the era.  Genealogy and DNA show that the upstairs men misbehaved with the downstairs women, so it's surprising to see Julian Fellowes depict the changing sexual era by having the upstairs women misbehaving.  Why is he so reluctant to have the upstairs men misbehave?
